content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
Early Access Review
TL;DR summary:Overall BeamNG.drive is one of the best soft body car shenanigans simulator out there, and it's completely worth its price. I bought the alpha early on, about a year ago, and I'm still having fun with it now. If you like the physicsy simulationy type of sandbox game you'll definitely be impressed with BeamNG.drive and end up messing around with it for a long time (and that's not including the wide variety of mods available)!There's a racing mode and other new features coming out soon, and I hope they turn out as well as everything else.Regarding Next Car Game, NCG is more of a desruction derby focusing on wide areas and chunks of destruction with a ton of broken pieces flying around; it's more of an action-orientated game. BeamNG.drive is a realistic physics simulator sandbox. NCG and BeamNG.drive are both good at doing what they are designed to do, but in my view they're pretty different. TL;DR reviewy thing:Crash Physics: The physics are extremely realistic and efficient with minimal glitching; every crash inflicts different and varying amounts of damage upon each vehicle.Car Detail: The cars are detailed in terms of aesthetics (the detail of the exterior and interior of the vehicles) and mechanics (wheel torque, suspension, chassis integrity) with results extremely similar to their real-world counterparts.Graphics and Sound: The graphics are decent with no visual effect bugging as of now. The sound works for what it is but isn't made all that well; a sound overhaul is planned.Mods: The mods are plenty and great, very high quality. You can pilot airplanes and do the coolest trix.Controls: There are many controls and it is sometimes hard to press all the buttons needed to control vehicles. Vehicles can sometimes feel sticky or slippery.For those who are willing to take upon themselves the challenge of reading a huge block of text:Summary:BeamNG.drive is one of the most realistic car physics/damage simulators up to date. Utilizing a real-time soft-body physics engine powered by Torque3D, it successfully emulates breakable and malleable surfaces applied to cars. The physics demonstration that BeamNG.drive is capable of is nearly identical to real-world movement; footage of in-game crashes have been compared to real-world test crashes with minimal differences.Reviewy thing:Crash Physics: It's amazing how the physics are simulated, with every surface on every car bending and breaking differently in every situation (surfaces are warped in accordance to the surfaces they come in contact with resulting in unique damage, rather than calling up a stored "damage model" when a car hits something a la GTA car physics or the such). This is where the "Beam" of BeamNG.drive comes in. I'm not that knowledgeable about the details of the physics simulating but it can be thought of like a detailed, intricate grid on a surface with each point moving when it hits something. I have not encountered many bugs in the physics so far, but if pushed far beyond real-world limits the physics do cause model glitches. Sometimes meshes and textures will crumple and stretch weirdly after paricularly intensive crashes. For what it is, however, it works wonderfully and efficiently, even able to be run on a medium-powered laptop with some lag spikes only during intensive car mangling.Car Detail: Each car is crafted with a keen eye to their details; the mechanics of a vehicle and the aesthetics are both represented. Each car has its unique statistics, with varying engine types, suspension, handling, and et cetera. The handling can even be changed, with options for a sportscar-like experience, offroad handling, and other presets. (The actual in-game control handling can be changed as well, ranging from an arcade control scheme seen in most car games to a full, realistic "driver's seat" experience. However, as of now the control is sort of lackluster with a keyboard since the left and right keys make the steering wheel turn all the way to either side; the cars sometimes feel sticky or slippery.) The detailed aesthetics can also be changed, as the cars are modular and can have parts added and removed. This also ties in with the modding capabilities of the game, which I will get into in a bit. Because of all of the attention paid to making everything as realistic as possible, the seven vanilla cars each have their own unique feel and excel at different tasks (again much like their real-world counterparts).Graphics and Sound: In my opinion, there's not much to say about this aspect currently since the focus of BeamNG.drive is realistic physics simulation. The graphics are decent and look great when maxed out, but they're nothing special currently (as you can probably see in the trailer and screenshots). There are some post effects which help to smooth everything out a bit, and there are a spattering of particles here and there. The particles do add a lot of effect when used correctly in screenshots and cinematics. The camera following sometimes goes through the ground if a car is tumbling or spinning but overall works as it should, providing smooth views of third-person and first-person views (although there's no model actually driving the cars). That covers the basic graphics system, I think. The sound isn't as good as everything else, but it is clear and works its part. The engine sounds, tire screeches, and et cetera are the same in every situation on every car but the actual sound clips are clear and concise. In slow motion the sounds run in realtime and are very loud, but other than that I can't think of anything too jarring. There is some ambience as well, and it is decent. The developers are planning a sound overhaul, however, so I am looking forwards to that.Mods: The modding capabilities really expand the possibilities of BeamNG.drive, with more detailed vehicles, intricate maps, other fun and interesting mods. There are many high quality mods that have qualities comparable to the actual game. One of the most well-known modders on the BeamNG forums, DrowsySam, has even helped the devs with some things. Of course, as mods, they aren't completely perfect but as I said, most of them are top notch. There are even mods for planes, and althought the physics for those aren't as realistic and smooth as the car physics, they're still pretty awesome (the devs haven't had air travel possibilities in their mids yet so hopefully you can see how cool that is), I'm also not going to say too much about this, since you really just have to install some mods to get a sense of what they can do.Controls: The controls are a bit weird, with the arrow keys controlling vehicles, the numpad and a right-click-and-hold controlling the camera, and various other key combinations for respawning, changing gears (in manual control mode), switching vehicles, and activating slow motion to list a few of the commonly used commands. It works, but sometimes it is hard to access multiple commands, for example, when trying to record something (movement, camera angle, and slow motion for example).EDIT: Formatting and added something about Next Car Game.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								Whilst I would recommend this game, there a few points I want to show.1) As a non-expert on cars it can be difficult when it comes to tuning when you have about 15 different sliders/values to change. It would be nice to have a few pre-sets I often found steering was difficult in a few cars (and I didn't understand what values/sliders to change to perhaps make it better) 2) This is a really fun 'sandbox' but to me it's not quite a game, if you want to spend your hours crashing cars a lot or zooming around then I'd say go for it. There's a local multi-player mode but if you're like me and you don't have friends in real life that will play with you then ¯\_(ツ)_/¯3) The price is expensive in comparison to what you're getting, just a suggestion but I would say about £10-£12 for this game max and you'd probably find you'd get a lot more sales.I'll come back to this game in the future and just have another looksie and see if these points mentioned have been addressed in a way. Overall this game is very advanced and the physics are really well done and when you crash the damage feels so realistic.9/10

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								TrackIR support (just added) and dialing in the FFB has really brought the immersion to the next level. The game is also running very, very smoothly with very low input latency. Performance is easily 2x over what it was a year ago, let alone when they first put the tech demo on their website,Using high and low filtering at 30, slightly increased max FFB and overall ffb strengths and 600 sampling. Each car feels believably unique, even each variant. Right now, I consider the FFB to be excellent, better than games like dirt rally and iracing. The cement mixer is so much more immursive and alive than any ETS2+ trucks. The devs have consistently worked away at all core issues and have really made a pretty special simulator.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								By far, my favorite Racing/Driving game at the moment. Amazing damage physics (as real as you will find), a promising future for the game play and content (Including an actual Semi to crush other vehicles with), and, of course, the open slate for modifications and level editors. I will admit, the controls are twitchy and keeping control is hard in this current state, but regardless, this game is a must have for any Automotive Enthusiast, no matter your involvement. The current customization may not be diverse, but it shows just how far they will take us into what you want your car to be. Truly, this is Automotive Heaven, it just isn't finished yet. Try the tech demo and feel for yourself:http://www.beamng.com/content/The biggest downside to this amazing game is the requirements to run it. I can run it on a smaller map with one vehicle, but even from that experience, i cannot wait to get a better PC, JUST for this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								I would like to pipe in and say that I absolutely love BeamNG Drive. There's nothing quite like it. It has its quirks, but as the game continues to mature, I find myself with less and less to complain about.Before you read further, let me advise you that you will need a beefy GPU for this game. I find it playable enough on my Nvidia GTX 960, and it's well optimised for what you're getting, but YMMV.Here's how I break the game down:+Unparalleled soft body vehicle physics model+Lots of beautiful, fully customizable stock cars that honestly just 'feel good' to drive+Awesome environments to drive around in+TONS of community content, most of which works and feels great. Installing mods is as easy as pressing a button.+The NG engine even supports aerial vehicles (No stock ones, but several quality mods for everything from bombers to helicopters)+Throw your car off a ♥♥♥♥ing cliff!!!! Reset, repeat.+Vehicles now catch on fire if you abuse them enough.+No huge races but the time rallies are a step in the right direction+Just go get yourself lost driving around in the jungle or desert. (If you just enjoy driving for what it is, you will LOVE this game.)-Requires a beefy computer. Not really a con if you have a quality rig, but buyer beware!-No multiplayer support (but there are rumors it's being worked on)Tl;dr: P̫͝͠r̛̲̤a̺̯̜̝̭͖͍i̶͟͏̙̘̭̱̹ş͎̀e̟͍̗̟ ̘̪̗̮̣̰̪ͅb̷̫͈e̸̡̢̼̼̜ ̖̜̯̝̹͔̝̰̮t̸̴̥̯̙̲͙͉͟ͅó̻̦̣̝̗̰͉̼ ̘̤͎͓͖̦͍͢͡É͏̲̗͢ͅT̮E̲̻̘R̸̵͈̟̳̭̺̪̜N̛҉̩̞͔̼͇̟̪̲A̺L̳̤̝̪̬ ̶̭͙̖̻̦Z͏̧̡̫͉A̧̮͙̕̕L̶̜̼̮̲̥̭̳͟G̨҉̴͙̱͖͕͕̰̙̞O͍̥͇̞̪͓͍ ͓̺̻̪͡f̼̝͖͍̰̟̤̺o̷̹̦̬̖͢r̴̴̛̻̝̩͈̯̜ͅ ̩̙̻̜̺̠̀t̵̛̗͎͚̬̠̝̥̕ͅh̘̰̫̠̗i̷̴͍̼̻̪͠s͏̴̢͖͓̱̞̺͎͍ ̧̯̺̞̯͇̭̕ͅq̨͉͇͔̪̝̀͞u̳͎̗̟̻̗͍̲̳ḁ̷̬͇̦̘͎̝͞l̻̱͡i̻̮ț̛͚̜̩̣̱̝̀͝y̨̳̭͉̠̥͓̝͡͠ ̧҉̹̣͖̖̙͍̘̯g̹͍͖̠̳͈̀á̷̺̹͍ḿ͕͈̖̫̙͚͜e̼͚̲̗͎̹͉͔.̘͖̝̻̹͎̪͟͡

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is not a game in the traditional sense.It is however the most satisfying damage physics I've ever controlled in a peice of playable software.The 'scenarios' allow you to challenge yourself to various checkpoint based time trials against the clock. But this is only a sideline compared to free-roaming the maps in various iterations of a modest but broad selection of very well modelled vehicles.If the future GTAs, Project Cars or similar can wrangle this kind of powerful physics then the future is bright for ultra-realistic, satisfying vehicular gameplay.You shouldn't be turned off by the Early Access nature of the game. The level which the game is at currently IS worth £19 in my opinion. However this might seem steep to anyone who prefers a story-lead game with a much more led set of scenarios.8/10 - If the updates stay regular, WELL worth it.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								In BeamNG.drive you can almost destroy your car/vehicle any way you want from crashing it into something as fast as you can or taking a truck to go obliterate it.  It's only single player right now and hopefully multiplayer will be added around final release.  The physics can get a bit wonky and things will fall off your vehicle from no stress at all nearly. When you get stuck inside something, there is a reset button for your vehicle and it's great but if your stuck between a prop and a wall, it sometimes won't work. If you like realistic cars this game is for you, but you need a good computer to run it.  it's early access so things are supposed to happen that will be fixed like bushes acting as invincible blocks that can destroy your vehicle to shreds and invincible trees acting as spider web when you drive into them too fast.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Good stuff about the game below. Will update this as more updates come. Right now I'm guessing it's maybe 1% finished. The only content in the game are maps and cars (of which 99% is made by community). But the core is there. Also there are a couple of missions and races to try after the last big update.There are some amazing vehicle mods out there. And there are a lot of fun maps, too. Most people MIGHT get bored from the current state of the game though because there is almost nothing to do: You just load a map, choose a car, and crash it as you please. Or don't. You can drive around if you want. That's it. Oh you can add a stupid AI to follow you or run from you but that's about it. You can also add multiple AIs. They are also working on AI improvements as well.Now on to the good stuff: + I cannot emphasize enough how good the crashing mechanic is (flagship feature). It's ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. The game's name derives from the fact that they are using the Beam technology on car design (I think it's their own engine). The cars are created out of beams. That's why crashes are so realistic and fun. Every beam gets deformed on its own, according to the applied force, the angle of the force, the momentum and♥♥♥♥♥♥+ Beautiful graphics. To my taste, this is cutting edge+ You can even mod your own engine sound+ Mod maps and cars, or download the ready ones+ Day/night concept is there (editable)+ Destruct your car in a variety of ways+ Multiple cameras (duh)+ Slow motion at your disposal+ You're in for a lot of laughs+ Or join the modding forums on the website and be surprised to find out that someone designed your dream car into the game. Now download and crush it.+ Career is coming at full release+ ♥♥♥♥in' A**The only con I can think of is the required system to play the game at it's full capacity. I'm sure they will optimize it further but right now as it is, the game needs a powerful computer to run. Especially when you spawn multiple cars to crash or enter a foresty area. When crashing multiple cars together, it might lag a lot on average computers.**It has a vast potential, and the devs are aiming for a free-roam, career thingy, in which you will be able to buy junk cars and reform them into racing machines or pretty eye candies, you will be able to complete jobs, missions, races, deliveries, derbies, free-roam, all of that.But that would be a long way off from now. They say the game will be in this phase for about a year from now. So buy at your own risk (not that it's a risk actually, there is just not any content right now).When this game gets finished, it might be the very first 'driving' game that I have given 10/10 my whole life. Because currently there isn't any open world 'driving' game with realistic driving concept which also includes careers and mods. There just isn't any. Any potential rival games that come close to this, either ruin it by sucking at graphics or by making it online, or by making it a linear racing game (don't even get me started on NFS series).So I recommend it for people who like to smash cars with the best possible physics available, and who like community made cars and maps, and a realistic driving.There is also wheel support with manual gears.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								I don't usually write reviews... ever actually. But I feel this game can't go without one. I've been playing this game since September of 2013 and it simply never gets old. There is a lot of talk about there not being much gameplay yet, which is partially true. It doesn't have a story mode or a campaign, (Not yet at least) but to be honest it doesn't need to. The normal sandbox mode is endless entertainment, and with the new addition of 'Scenarios', (Time trials and timed challenges) there is more playable content than ever. The scenarios are actually quite difficult and it will surely take many hours to complete them all. And on top of that, you can share your times with members on the forum to be put on a leaderboard. Aside from the scenarios though, it's really a game meant for imagination and experimentation. Just thinking of every way possible to wreck any car I want leaves endless possibilities. As a kid who grew up on racing games, I've always dreamed of a game where every action you have has an equal reaction. One where you actually have to drive carefully in order to succeed. And that's exactly what BeamNG is. You can spend endless hours on this game whether you're crashing cars, flying planes, (And even sailing ships, soon) offroading, stunting, and even content creating with the excellent mod support this game has. It may get boring after an hour or two of just driving around and exploring, but for some reason I always keep coming back to it. I'll admit, it's not for everyone. It requires patience, imagination, and a curious mind. But honestly, if you've ever been interested in doing outrageous things with vehicles that you could never do in real life, than this is the game you need to get. It offers a ridiculous number of possibilities with real-life outcomes. It's truly the most realistic driving game I've ever played.Pros:Insanely beautiful graphics.Lifelike soft-body physics.Enough maps, cars, and objects to keep you entertained for days.Multiple 'Scenarios' where you can test your time and driving skill.Very advanced settings so you can set EVERYTHING perfectly.Customizable UI with multiple interesting apps.Camera mode for easy, beautiful screenshots.Extremely realistic vehicles. The models/textures are nearly exact in every aspect.Working dashboards, gas tanks, lights, and trailers.Real-life aerodynamics, time, gravity, and physics.Crazy props to destroy your cars with.Realistic maps that can take hours to explore.Time trials on supported mapsAmazing forum community.Easy mod support from the talented modders on the forum.*Mods such as planes, boats, offroaders, machines, maps, skins, apps, and more.Relatively easy to mod yourself, if you have the time to learn.TRULY regular updates. It's a small team but they really stepped up.Cons:Takes a decent computer to run well.Probably boring if you aren't a little creative.Crashes often (But what can you expect when you slam a car into a wall at 300mph in a virtual physics engine that's early access?)I don't personally use a racing wheel, but I hear the game has little support for them. I'd look into that more if this applies to you.TL;DRIf you've ever wanted to see or do anything crazy with a vehicle that you can't do in real life, buy this game. It's one of the most good-looking games I've ever seen, and it's the most realistic physics simulator I've ever seen. If you are at all interested in it, just get it.*I'd like to make this very clear that I said "on the forum". Never download a mod that wasn't originally posted to the official BeamNG forum. Around the BeamNG community, a few Russian websites have become very well known for publishing false mods. They are simple vehicle models ripped off from somewhere on the internet and then slapped onto the jbeam (The code and skeleton that makes vehicles in this game crash and function) of an existing default vehicle. This results in, for example, a car that looks like a Lamborghini but handles and crashes like a Crown Vic. These mods could have viruses in them, and without a doubt will not function well. If you do insist to download these however, I believe I speak for the community when I say to not publish videos or pictures of them. Like I said, they don't function the way they're meant to and in short, just make the game look bad. I just thought I'd give a fair warning.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								As of 6/17/2015: EARLY ACCESS.In it's current state, it's more of a car accident simulator than an actual game, though there are a few pre-cursors to a career mode - a few challenges and such.   This aside, let's get on to the real deal here.     An absolutely hands-down realistic soft-body driving simulator, most likely more realistic than what you see in drivers training computer systems.  Not only can you shift gears (multiple transmission modes, arcade automatic, real auto, manual, manual with clutch), you can use signals, hazard lights, headlights/highbeams, and the signal stalks and shifter moves as you shift it - gauges work too and if you clobber the car so badly the check-engine light comes on!.  It's extremely well thought-out, and if you ever have played Rig-of-Rods, it's all the fun that was, and way way more fun.      Welcome to the "Garry's Mod" of CARS.  I can't really explain it better than that.  When you fly too fast through a corner, and understeer, and nail a tree, your car becomes a crumpled undriveable mess of mangled steel.  This isn't GTA, this is a real simulation @ 2000hz (hz=times per second), with thousands of bits for each car.  Due to this, you need a beefy CPU to run this game well and a decent video card to go with it.  Anything i5/i7 or Phenom II quad core or better should run this, and it should be playable on an APU setup or i3 setup without too much fuss, though you might slow it down if you use the commercial truck as it has considerably more points to process.    MODS:  Loads of user-generated content for both vehicles and terrains (maps, levels etc), are available on the games website once you purchase the game.  You won't be let down by this as myself I am a big fan of game modding.  This program also INCLUDES ITS OWN LEVEL EDITOR INSIDE!  Woohoo!  More fun, and it's pretty intuitive to use, your mileage may vary.      For it's asking price, it's well worth it.  While it's not yet complete, this is more an adults game or a mechanics toy.  If you love cars, and realism, do give this a go!  You can even get computer controlled AI opponents to use if you dig around through the menus and figure it out - though in it's current state, it's either basic pursuit or to FLEE.  Can be quite fun near a steep cliff!     You can even change things like GRAVITY (or reverse gravity!) or make it the gravity of the SUN *CRUNCH*.  Wind direction/speed and cloud cover/fog can all be changed - though I am not sure if you can make it rain (yet) or not.   There's no music yet, and the sounds are quite basic at this point, but there is enough audio feedback to know what's going on, and it will be worked on more.  The graphics are beautiful (I think it's the crytek crysis 3 engine - don't quote me on it though) - and entirely up to par with today's game environments - but still scalable to your PC.  I have a recent model i7 and a radeon 7850 2gb and it runs this quite well with next to no lag.  SSD recommended but by no means required.  Some user levels can be 2gb so if you don't like to wait, put this on your SSD.   Keep in mind, when the game updates, you will have to re-install your mods (this won't usually be the case post-release but in pre-release early access it is, so just be warned!).  Keep your favorite mods backed up.    All in all, it's a good program for adults, and something to show your kid WHY NOT TO DRIVE TOO FAST!    A great program for the soon-to-be-driving teen-age member of your family!  Best used with a steering wheel or analog gamepad, as it may take quite a bit of time to get used to driving with a keyboard - it's that realistic.AGAIN:  HAVE AN ANALOG GAMEPAD OR STEERING WHEEL FOR THIS GAME, it's an absolute @$^# to drive with a keyboard (but it can be done, but you will crash A LOT).  Use the 'Covet' if you have only a keyboard and GO SLOW.Fun times - whole-heartedly recommended - a well made program!  I seriously have nothing bad to say on this one other than the fact that it's NOT done yet (but it will be!).Update 11/9/2015:  Played a demo-derby scenario - most awesome demo derby ever since Destruction Derby for dos in the mid-to-late 90's.  This is available on the beamng website under mods - you must try it!  Also, races with jumps and Honda spoon Civics ("Covet") and that's fun as can be.  You must give this game a shot, for 25 USD you can't go wrong!Update 12/2015:  Got a SCHOOL BUS vehicle out of the mods section on the game's web site, and a map with a large CLIFF.  Much fun & hilarity ensued.  Many pixels were injured in the making of that one.  Would bust the bus again 10/10.Update 1/1/2016:  Two recent updates have brought game version to 0.5.1, Two new cars, turbo and tuning systems galore, being able to mod the vehicle like you could back in STREET LEGAL, it's really becoming an awesome game/simulator.  More options now, more sounds (yay!), cars can catch fire, and the two new cars mentioned above (a vintage old 1950s car, and a 1988 import sedan) are pretty rockin' awesome.  Back to more fun on the large-cliff-map!

content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								BeamNG interview between me and myself.Me: So how do you like BeamNG?Myself: I love crashing cars!Me: There are many games where you can smash cars. What makes this game so great?Myself: Three words. Soft. Body. Physics.Me: Soft body physics? Can you elaborate?Myself: Realistic and unlimited vehicle body deformation. More than any game before it. Before BeamNG there was Rigs of Rods. Burnout 3: Takedown has the best vehicular damage in the Burnout series. But that game did not simulate every component of the vehicle. Carmagedon, Dirt, Grid, Flatout and Crashtime all have pretty amazing vehicle physics. BNG is just leaps and bounds ahead of everyone.Me: Would you recommend the game, even in the early access state?Myself: Absolutely yes! If your PC can handle it. This is probably the only thing holding the game back. The game is still a work in progress so at times the game runs great, other times not so much. There is a mod community already making vehicles for the game. These can be hit and miss as different versions of the game come out compatiblity changes. So if you find a car that just falls apart you might have to uninstall that mod. The developer content in the game is great so far. Constantly adding new vehicles, maps and scenarios to play. I just love to load up a map and play around with the many vehicle types. It's essentially a physics playground of vehiclular vehicle slaughter.Me: Wow! that is a lot to take in. Hopefully this answered some questions for the community looking to buy.Myself: Well if you want you can swing over to my profile page and check out some of the screenshots that I took in game.Me: Great. I will. Thank you for our time.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's not really a driving game, it's more of a car simulator. Like Spintires, but with a heavy focus on soft body destruction. The video below shows some real life car crashes recreated in beam.ng and it should really drive home what an impressive piece of software this is. Its fun to try things that would get you killed in real life and watch how a car would respond, but it;s also fun just tooling around in really accurately physics modeled cars and watch your pick up truck stall out on a steep incline, or shift gears too quick and throw a rod, or whatever. Also there are tons of things to download on the forums where there is a huge community of moders. It's not a racing game or whatever but it's a very cool thing and if you are on the fence I would certainly recommend it.


YouTube™ Video: BeamNG.drive VS Real Life (Physics & Damage Comparison) 

			Views: 1,437,662		

			Side by side comparison between BeamNG & reallife crashes. I recreated some known scenarios from real life in BeamNG.drive to show you how realistic the soft body physics are.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								As it stands, BeamNG is an incredibly fun vehicle-crashing sandbox with amazing soft body physics. Promises of career modes and other such things aside, BeamNG already contains a decently sized selection of meticulously detailed maps and vehicles--and even more are available to download thanks to the modding community.As of writing this though, this IS still very much an alpha. I haven't experienced any instability but the sounds are still placeholders and some things like the UI and the tyre physics could use some polishing. Still, I personally find it very enjoyable in its current state.If you enjoy destruction-based sandboxes such as Red Faction, or are frustrated with the pathetic vehicle damage models from driving games these days, then this is for you.

Go to Local Disk (C:) – Users – you're user – Steam – steamapps – common – BeamNG. Drive – content – vehicles. In the vehicles folder paste the mods there.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								A perfectly fine game to pass some down time and relieve stress.The developers are great, the modding community is great (stay away from the forums, they are cancer) and the time spent in game is great.Plenty of cars, varied maps and gameplay options to keep you interested for a little while. It can get boring if you can't think up too much to do since it's still just a glorified simulator. If you can find fun, you will be able to play for hours thanks to the freedom you have in the game.The graphics are pretty trashy, the game runs on an engine that for all intents and purposes came out in 2002. Most of the other games in the engine are 2d platformer games. It runs like a person with downs syndrome. I have 2 gtx 970s, and since the engine does not take advantage of SLI, it only uses one. I struggle to keep 60fps on some parts of some maps, and forget about that with more than one vehicle. This is on a mix of medium-high setting with AA disabled, and dynamic reflections set to about medium. For reference, I can run GTA V at 90+ FPS on ultra settings no problem. Looks worse than GTA V and runs worse than GTA V. Do not buy if you can't stand terrible graphics.The updates are somewhat frequent, there are probably about 30 people full time working on it and maybe they push an update a month an a half. Last update was october 4th, and the update before that came out July 27th. Each update usually adds a new car, and adds or overhauls a driving mechanic. The october 4th update added campaigns, with no new car, the July update added brake thermals, the update before that added engine thermals, and the next update will hopefully add new drivetrain phtsics.I'm rambling here. Its a good game.

								I bought this game the day it came out which is over a year ago now (a year before they added it to steam). I remember waiting for the countdown timer to be up on their website so i could buy this game, i have seen the development processes and the dev team is amazing. This is the most realist driving/crashing game you can get. This game uses Soft Body physics which you don't get in really any game (Next Car Game for example). If you want to spend many many hours driving around, or maybe crashing into things or messing with the gravity, This game is for you. content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a great game.  I've always loved driving games that simulated damage and whatnot.  Need for Speed once used to do this, and I loved it.  Only when they started making cars only get a scratch for hitting a wall at 200 mph, did I start to lose interest.  BeamNG.Drive has revived the driving simulator for me with its amazing soft body physics, and fully simulated components!Ya know when you hit a curb in a car going too fast, and your alignment is all out of whack, or worse, you break something?  Yeah, that can happen in this game.  I'd highly recommend playing this with a bare minimum of a game pad.  If you have a Yolk and pedals, or a steering wheel and pedals, that would be even better.The roads aren't all smooth and perfect either, watch out for those potholes, they'll really mess you up.  Even patches where the road has been repaired has a slight bumb, which at 80 miles per hour, is enough quite often to send you flipping end over end, ultimately wrapping your car around a tree!Drive dangerously my friends, it's a blast!

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
Product received for free
Early Access Review
Some of the finest physics I've seen.BeamNG.drive is a driving game/tech demo hybrid with an impressive amount of detail and surprisingly addicting. Having started as a proof-of-concept in the CryEngine by the former developers of Rigs of Rods - another very similar, more rudimentary game focusing on trucks and heavy vehicles, it has since switched to the Torque3D engine to handle the physics.There's no storyline or career as of yet. Updates have added a selection of campaigns to complete, such as a driver's license test and wrecking stuff up.It's a pretty game, for sure, but don't go nuts with the dynamic car reflections if you treasure your framerate. Rather odd post-processing artifacts, or that might be me just not knowing how to work with them. Crashes look a little bland without particles or extra bits flying out.Sounds remain fairly basic, with the standard game offering a grand total of two distinct engine notes without mods: an Inline 4 and a V6/V8. No soundtrack, either. The variety of impact, crash and general effects is increasing, at least.The selling point lies in the revolutionary soft body physics. At the expense of requiring an ever more powerful CPU to simulate multiple cars interacting with each other, you get what is possibly the most accurate car deformation, period. While it remains prone to clipping, gripping and other odd issues, 99% of the time it is consistent and logical.An ever expanding list of official cars cover more or less any stereotype conceivable, and if you can think of more, there's mods to remedy that too. You can drive a 4-wheel steering sedan, a pickup truck for your hillbilly rock climbing purposes, a surprisingly fun and nimble hatchback, a dangerously difficult 70's supercar, and many, many more. All of them, of course, have varying tolerances to crashes from whichever direction, but also a healthy collection of parts to choose from. Slap a stage 4 supercharger kit on your muscle car and rocket to terrifying speeds - and send your engine temperature shooting, your wheels screeching due to no grip, and your hapless car careening into walls.It is such a robust and well built engine that it can simulate airplanes and helicopters, lift and drag, and all sorts of intricate stages of mechanical failures like blown engine gaskets, fried piston rings, bent connecting rods, broken driveshafts, snapped axles, faded-out brakes, so on and so forth. It has taken a few years to get to this point, but man: it is the most impressive evolution of a game I've ever seen, from release until now.Mods further increase the game's variety, with aforementioned planes, helicopters, and varying flavours of land vehicles and configurations. Simple to install and remove (usually).Updates are somewhat slow to deliver, but when they land, you should expect a couple more cars, a lot more car variation, and several new, possibly experimental systems to improve the simulation aspects of the game. I dare say the devs have picked up significant momentum as of late, and they're eeking ever closer to proper LAN, or even online multiplayer. Until then, we have replays and AI control to bring our destruction derby and "Slightly more sensible Crash Junction" dreams to life.It is totally worth the money if you're a car/physics nut. It surely is deep in its mechanics, but the current content is a bit too thinly spread to easily warrant a purchase for anyone else; patience is a more wise idea when tackling Early Access titles, even better developed ones such as this.

Early Access Review
								This is deformable vehicle physics at it's finest. It looks good and is enjoyable to drive. You can use a controller, wheel/pedals or keyboard for controls. Both the controller and the wheel settings are configurable. Vehicle customization is easy and intuitive while the track selection is just as pleasant. You can hop right in and go if You choose. You can play with objectives. You can even build your own vehicles with a little external editing. I have seen airplanes and boats that work perfectly. There are not many limitations with this one. I recommend this for the advanced vehicle tinkerer or modeler. I also recommend this to everyone who is into driving simulators and games as this is a perfect companion to anything you are currently driving.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is definitely one of the best racing games I've ever played.  Its fun, realistic, and creative, thanks to the dedicated mod community and wonderful devs who keep us updated on their website beamng.com/blogs/ with a weekly summary of their work.  I've put at least 20 hours into the game before it came on Steam, and I have no intention of stopping.  This game already has no ceiling to how amazing it can be, and there isn't even any sort of structure to the gameplay.  Its a simple load map, load vehicle, drive to your heart's content affair that is both incredibly relaxing and engagig.  I love making rally courses to run through without wrecking and just running through them over and over.  There is no time limit, no opponents, and no objectives.  Only you, the car, and the road.  The great bit is that each game is a new adventure because there aren't any rules as to where you can and can't go, leaving it up to you to decide how to explore and play with the environment you're given.  And then there is the main selling point of this game: the crash physics.  How the devs did it, I have no idea.  Watching your car get bent in half around a tree after a botched high-speed turn is a sight like no other.  For those of us hell-bent on obliderating our cars, there is a map called "Insane Testing" by Insanegaz on the mod forums featuring spikes, loops, giant stairs, huge drops, high speed cliff races, and all kinds of terrains to smash your vehicle on.  As well as being a great game to play, it is also a great game to mod.  The world editor can be accessed by pressing F12 in game, and it uses a simple and intuitive UI that makes it easy to create your own content.  On the coding side, everything is done in LUA, which is incredibly simple to learn.  Installing mods is as easy as downloading one from the forums, unzipping the package and dropping the folder into the appopriate directory within the game file ("Levels" for new maps, "Vehicles" for new cars, etc.).Of course, there are a few problems with the game, but that is to be expected of a private Alpha build.  The engine sound is the same for all cars, and the tire screech is not pleasant either.  There is currently no multiplayer, although I expect that to come eventually.   At the time of writing, the dev team is in the process of crafting a massive update nicknamed the "Race Update" because it is to add a structured race system complete with laps, checkpoints, and working AI (non-player vehicles are currently a feature, and they do have AI, but only "Flee from player" and "Chase player", both of which are tons of fun already).  Some of the controls are a little obtuse (I'm sure they're just placeholders that will be changed by Beta), and there isn't any GUI for customizing your controls.  In fact, you have to find your inputmaps.dae file and manually edit things, which is a little annoying, but not a game-killer.  While the crash physics are amazing, the rest of the graphics fall a little short.  As a whole, the textures are somewhat lifeless and the lighting isn't advanced enough yet to add a solid tonal feel to the game.  BUT, the game isn't anywhere close to being done and I am quite impressed at the quality and sheer amount of fun present in this piece of software.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								At first I saw this game as a fun crash simulator. As I played more, I became fascinated at how realistic the driving physics are, despite employing a completely different paradigm to anything else. In the past, i've found physics based titles (not just car games) to have a plethora of silly physics glitches, making them difficult to play or impossible to take seriously. I bought a Thrustmaster T300RS Racing wheel recently, and despite having a dozen other car games in my collection, I find myself coming back to this one. It really shines with a wheel, and you'll find that the force feedback is a unique experience compared to anything else. Oh and the crashes are spectacular of course.Recommended.PROS+ Surprisingly nice graphics, looks almost raytraced at times+ Novel approach to vehicle handling that that is fun but realistic+ Industry-leading softbody physics+ Good controller support, with support for shifters and clutch pedals. I'm even using an old joystick as a handbrake.+ Force feedback for wheels is great when tuned+ Mod support; more vehicles, more maps, more funCONS- Poor performance on a 980 Ti a good bit of the time. 45-50 FPS in a lot of maps.- Needs some tweaking to get ingame steering wheels to turn 1:1 with your wheel controller- No multiplayer... yetNEUTRAL- VR support better be on the roadmap- Steam Workshop would be better than the current mod install system

content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game exists solely to show off the soft body physics of the cars.  That being said, it does it in spectacular form.  Its absolutely hilarious.  At this point, the game is in alpha, which they make very clear going in, so as it is at the time of this writing, there's not a lot of content.  I've also come across a couple of bugs, but its pretty stable as a whole.  There are several maps that are fully explorable, a handful of vehicles with different variations, and some scenarios to play with are available, but it's best to try and make your own fun.  The game supports mods as well, but I haven't been able to get any to work yet.  Its thoroughly entertaining overall, so I am excited to see what else gets added to the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's actually pretty good. You do need to mind the system requirements though as the graphics look nice but hit your system hard especially on starting a session since the game loads the entire map and every little part on every car at once. As for the gameplay the collision effects are really well done and you can do whatever you want to. The sound effects really are poor and fake sounding though as most mobile games have better sound effects and the handling of the cars is unrealistically poor. But it does have pretty fun levels and challenges you can do to make you realize just how fragile cars are. Like oh you hit a rock at 5mph now your steering needs to be fixed. It's coming across like a vehicle based Gmod since you can also just mess around with physics. But like Gmod it does lack content at its base level and so mods and multiplayer are needed to really make the game great. Unfortunately the modding is not very streamlined and would be better through the steam workshop or a dedicated mod site like nexus. If you want to add real cars you need to search around for them on all sorts of sites and clearing the cache to fix texture bugs removes them you'll always need to keep backups. In the end it's just a fairly fun way to pass some time but the mechanics and sound aren't polished enough to get immersed into it. Because there is no real objective it's hard to call it a game. It's more like software with games in it and mostly challenges you make for yourself right now. Gotta use your imagination until it gets to the point where you don't have to.Overall it's pretty good for an alpha car/physics sim but nowhere near beta or release quality. I'd wait for proper mod support unless you are a car enthusiast in which case I'd suggest buying it whenever it is on sale.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								BeamNG Drive Early Access. I bought this game a while back and I finally got a Steam key. So here is my review. BeamNG Drive is a driving simulator but not really. I think it is more of a vehicle crash simulator. The crash physics are great and the driving physics are getting there. I really like it. The biggest thing that bugs me is the computer performance. Now, I may not have a gaming PC but I can play other games on medium-high graphics and have no trouble. But on this game, it struggles. A little problem is clipping and fall-through. Clipping is when I crash into another vehicle and the textures clip into each other. Therefore wedging the cars together. Fall-through is my term when a car falls through another car. For example, loading the hatchback into the box truck (of course I remove the doors). I drive the car in and it falls out the bottom of the truck. The bad parts are little enough where the good parts stand out. Overall, a great game. I recommend it.

								I love Beamng.drive. I just hooked up my Xbox One controller to it and I've been having a blast. There are so many community created maps and vehicles and such. Physics are amazing.Well, I was having a blast.Now, as of around the 23rd, whenever I am on the start screen, I move my mouse the slightest inch and my frames drop to 0. And then I wait. And then they go back up to 60 ish, way less than what I was getting before this issue happened, when I was getting around 300-500 fps. This only affects the menu screen, but then when I finally load into the map, it brings me to my second issue, below.I have since lost all my vehicles and maps, and whenever I go into the files to make sure they weren't deleted, they are there. But in-game, they are simply not there. Gone like they were never there in the first place. Again, it's a beautiful game, with plenty of things to mess around with, and create some painstakingly accurate car crashes, if that's what you want. The physics are accurate down to the smallest dent, and I'm waiting for the multiplayer so that we can all turn our cars and trucks into flattened pancakes of metal.I'm checking the recommended box, just because I know that the developers can easily get over this simple, but very irritating issue.Fix your♥♥♥♥♥♥ Beamng, and I will play again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								I played a lot of video games in my youth. But I put them away when I reached adulthood. But one day I saw the BeamNG Drive trailer and was impressed. And so for the first time in about 20 years, I bought a video game.  Yes, only a game this good could break my 20 year drought!This is seriously the best video game I have ever played! The game offers the rare combination of being simple yet profound. It's uncomplicated to play, but allows you to do so much. The producers continue to innovate with each new update, making the game better and better and more interesting. The graphics and maps are often visually stunning with incredible detail. Many of the maps are so interesting with so much to do, they could almost be separate video games themselves. Plus, I love how other people can create maps, vehicles and props for the game. I also love the flexibility the game provides. In free roam, you can make up your own missions and goals. As well, if you're short on time, you can teleport to any place on the map, rather than spend time driving there. One of the game's best features is the soft-body physics technology, which makes crashes exceedingly realistic. Plus, there are almost endless ways you can damage and crash your car. It never gets old! It's so powerful that rather than merely playing a game, you're having a new experience! Just be aware the game is demanding on your computer. A graphics card is recommended but not required, if you have a pretty good computer. However, a few minor  features in the game may not available without a graphics card.In sum, BeamNG Drive equals video games at their best. BeamNG Drive is the quintessential driving, crashing and racing video game and the gold standard. I believe this game will be the top video game of the 21st century. Don't miss out and give it a whirl!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								This review is based on the alpha version of the game, up to the date August 11th, 2014.If you like realism, destruction, and cars, this is the game for you. I'd like to begin by discussing what exactly Drive is. Drive is a state-of-the-art physics simulator that runs Torque 3D as the main physics engine. In this environment, every movement and input is calculted and recalculted over and over again as the game moves. So, as you come around a corner with your tail out, the computer is taking your car's weight, road surface, throttle, brake, gas, size of the contact patch of the tires, and many more variables into account every second. This allows the game to make an accurate representation of what is going on. Continuing with my example, if you nicked a bump in the road, millions more calcultions would take place, throwing the car around and whatnot. Another important feature that is simulated is air, which, for the time being, is being experimented with."So, what do you do in this physics game?" Well, most of us from the beginning have been obsessed with cars and destroying them, so, that's what we do. We take vans and drop them onto hatchbacks; we take hatchs, and put jets on them, and then run them into the wall at 300mph. We also create the game. Due to the producing company's small size (under 15 people total at last check), the community up until now has aided in adding content to the game in the form of maps, vehicles, UI apps (compass, speedo's, tachs, etc), and more. Others constantly push the game, such as accidently making a working plane and several helicopters that are flyable (albiet with primitive controls, depending on the model). As a gamer, having all of this content available for free is awesome. And it's usually good quality stuff that the creators have put hours and weeks into. And it's free. "I'm a creator/artist/coder/computer wizz. How can I get involved?"I'm not sure how this'll work with the game porting over to Steam, but up until now, you would do whatever you'd normally create aand then put in the game. It's quite simple, and the game itself is built to be modded easily (the devs even have a wiki on how to do it). Modelors can make their models in any 3D program, export to COLLADA, create a "JBeam" file, and you're in. Obviously it takes more than just that, but it's a very straight-forward process that even a beginner could do successfully."Should I buy this?"Yes. There's more in the game that can be covered in this review without getting boring, but it is an extremely well-done game. Even though it's only in alpha, it's a pretty good game. Tech support from the community and devs is great, and gme-wide issues are quickly resolved. The physics are great and getting better, the view is spectacular, and who doesn't like smashing cars into each other? Oh, and did I mention the DLC is free? The DLC is free.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you love cars and all the physic's that go with them, then this game is for you. If' you're looking for the next racing game however, keep looking. BeamNG is the most realistic physic's simulatior I've ever played, is it perfect? Absolutly not. But it's very very good, among the best of the few games it compares to. It is so easy to turn on some music, or listen to book on tape and get lost for hours on end just driving around in your sandbox, racing, crashing, towing, testing or just exploring. Perhaps most importantly the dev's actually care about this game...One of the drawbacks to buying / playing early access game's is that it is often a gamble. A lot time's the devs become tired with their product and halt devolpment all together, leaving you with a hole in your wallet and a half finished product that'll never be more than that. That however, is not the case here. I owned this game for almost a year now, and throughout that year I have witnessed consistent improvements, patch's and added content. I cannot praise this game enough, I don't have the time to invest thousands of hours playing games like some people do. But I beleive this is my second most played game on steam...Only surpassed by Skyrim, and for the record BeamNG is closing fast on my Skyrim hours. The game has a decent arsenal of vehicles, ranging from your run of the mill work truck (which can modified to suit your taste) to Race cars, to Semi tractor trailers. And the fact, that this game is Steam Workshop compatible mean's that even more vehicle's and track's are just a click away!I'm trying to think of some potential ''con's'' to weigh in with all the ''pro's'' that go with this game. Personally I would like to see even more customization implimented into the game, such as the ability to tune gear ratio's in the transmission and fine tune things like aero dynamics. It would also be nice to be able to add specific upgrade's to your vehicle's engine. As it stand's right now, most vehicle's have Stage 1 Stage 2 and Stage 3 engine tune's and/or intake's that give you three stage's of horsepower/torque. But that's really just cherry picking on my behalf. Let's see what else, For those of you who enjoy playing with others...This is not your game. To my knowledge it currently does not have any form of multiplayer. No internet race's, I heard one time that it has split screen playability, but it's not something I've ever tried to use. I've heard some complaint's that this game only run's good on bad♥♥♥♥♥desktops, which is not completely true, however their's some truth in that statement. My current desktop was top the of line...Eight years ago, which my graphic's turned down a bit I can run most of BeamNG just fine. Howver, until I get a new computer I cannot play on certian level's...Like Moab, it's just to much for my old machine. On the side of sound, it's currently fairly weak. All vehicle's sound the same, a turbo I4 sounds excatly the same as a modified big block V8 in this game, so there isn't a huge veriety in that area, but hopefully that'll be improved upon in future patch's...Personally I just play with the sound off and listen to Reddit horror stories on Youtube while playing. With that said, It's time to tally up the Pro's and Con's.(Pros)AMAZING Physics.Reliable Devs who invest in their product to make consistent improvementsPotential to get lost for hours playing.Immense depth in level's, lot's of exploration to be done.Decent veriety of vehicle's ranging from Pickups to Race cars to Semi's.Supports Steam Workshop, meaning downloadedable vehicle's and tracks are just a click away.(Cons)Taxing to run at high resolution.Needs a little more depth in vehicle tuning.Lame sound effects.In it's current state I give this game a solid (9/10)It was worth every penny I spent on it. I hope you enjoyed this review!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								I played a lot of video games in my youth. But I put them away when I reached adulthood. But one day I saw the BeamNG Drive trailer and was impressed. And so for the first time in about 20 years, I bought a video game.  Yes, only a game this good could break my 20 year drought!This is seriously the best video game I have ever played! The game offers the rare combination of being simple yet profound. It's uncomplicated to play, but allows you to do so much. The producers continue to innovate with each new update, making the game better and better and more interesting. The graphics and maps are often visually stunning with incredible detail. Many of the maps are so interesting with so much to do, they could almost be separate video games themselves. Plus, I love how other people can create maps, vehicles and props for the game. I also love the flexibility the game provides. In free roam, you can make up your own missions and goals. As well, if you're short on time, you can teleport to any place on the map, rather than spend time driving there. One of the game's best features is the soft-body physics technology, which makes crashes exceedingly realistic. Plus, there are almost endless ways you can damage and crash your car. It never gets old! It's so powerful that rather than merely playing a game, you're having a new experience! Just be aware the game is demanding on your computer. A graphics card is recommended but not required, if you have a pretty good computer. However, a few minor  features in the game may not available without a graphics card.In sum, BeamNG Drive equals video games at their best. BeamNG Drive is the quintessential driving, crashing and racing video game and the gold standard. I believe this game will be the top video game of the 21st century. Don't miss out and give it a whirl!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you love cars and all the physic's that go with them, then this game is for you. If' you're looking for the next racing game however, keep looking. BeamNG is the most realistic physic's simulatior I've ever played, is it perfect? Absolutly not. But it's very very good, among the best of the few games it compares to. It is so easy to turn on some music, or listen to book on tape and get lost for hours on end just driving around in your sandbox, racing, crashing, towing, testing or just exploring. Perhaps most importantly the dev's actually care about this game...One of the drawbacks to buying / playing early access game's is that it is often a gamble. A lot time's the devs become tired with their product and halt devolpment all together, leaving you with a hole in your wallet and a half finished product that'll never be more than that. That however, is not the case here. I owned this game for almost a year now, and throughout that year I have witnessed consistent improvements, patch's and added content. I cannot praise this game enough, I don't have the time to invest thousands of hours playing games like some people do. But I beleive this is my second most played game on steam...Only surpassed by Skyrim, and for the record BeamNG is closing fast on my Skyrim hours. The game has a decent arsenal of vehicles, ranging from your run of the mill work truck (which can modified to suit your taste) to Race cars, to Semi tractor trailers. And the fact, that this game is Steam Workshop compatible mean's that even more vehicle's and track's are just a click away!I'm trying to think of some potential ''con's'' to weigh in with all the ''pro's'' that go with this game. Personally I would like to see even more customization implimented into the game, such as the ability to tune gear ratio's in the transmission and fine tune things like aero dynamics. It would also be nice to be able to add specific upgrade's to your vehicle's engine. As it stand's right now, most vehicle's have Stage 1 Stage 2 and Stage 3 engine tune's and/or intake's that give you three stage's of horsepower/torque. But that's really just cherry picking on my behalf. Let's see what else, For those of you who enjoy playing with others...This is not your game. To my knowledge it currently does not have any form of multiplayer. No internet race's, I heard one time that it has split screen playability, but it's not something I've ever tried to use. I've heard some complaint's that this game only run's good on bad♥♥♥♥♥desktops, which is not completely true, however their's some truth in that statement. My current desktop was top the of line...Eight years ago, which my graphic's turned down a bit I can run most of BeamNG just fine. Howver, until I get a new computer I cannot play on certian level's...Like Moab, it's just to much for my old machine. On the side of sound, it's currently fairly weak. All vehicle's sound the same, a turbo I4 sounds excatly the same as a modified big block V8 in this game, so there isn't a huge veriety in that area, but hopefully that'll be improved upon in future patch's...Personally I just play with the sound off and listen to Reddit horror stories on Youtube while playing. With that said, It's time to tally up the Pro's and Con's.(Pros)AMAZING Physics.Reliable Devs who invest in their product to make consistent improvementsPotential to get lost for hours playing.Immense depth in level's, lot's of exploration to be done.Decent veriety of vehicle's ranging from Pickups to Race cars to Semi's.Supports Steam Workshop, meaning downloadedable vehicle's and tracks are just a click away.(Cons)Taxing to run at high resolution.Needs a little more depth in vehicle tuning.Lame sound effects.In it's current state I give this game a solid (9/10)It was worth every penny I spent on it. I hope you enjoyed this review!

content:

Early Access Review
								If you like cars and crashing cars this is the game for you. Beamng Drive is a soft body physics game where you can crash cars, throw cars off cliffs, bend cars, customize your cars and then crash them, or just test the suspension. Ive been waiting forever for a game like this to come out and i think it was worth the wait. I love this game to bits but there are some cons: It lags, (a bit) it can be pretty glitchy sometimes, you do need a pretty beefy computer to run it, it crashes sometimes but not to much. The pros about this game: its physics are amazing, cars are very detailed from the interors to the exterors, abunch of cars to choose from, the mods are awesome, there are a few maps to choose from, maps are detailed. This is a awesome game and if you have a pretty good computer and you like crashing cars or if you just like cars this is a game for you. Its totaly worth the $20.   :3

								Alright, so I've been following softbody physics games since rigs of rods and I was sceptical about buying beam.ng drive as I felt that although there was LOADS of potential it would never achieve it. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's actually pretty good. You do need to mind the system requirements though as the graphics look nice but hit your system hard especially on starting a session since the game loads the entire map and every little part on every car at once. As for the gameplay the collision effects are really well done and you can do whatever you want to. The sound effects really are poor and fake sounding though as most mobile games have better sound effects and the handling of the cars is unrealistically poor. But it does have pretty fun levels and challenges you can do to make you realize just how fragile cars are. Like oh you hit a rock at 5mph now your steering needs to be fixed. It's coming across like a vehicle based Gmod since you can also just mess around with physics. But like Gmod it does lack content at its base level and so mods and multiplayer are needed to really make the game great. Unfortunately the modding is not very streamlined and would be better through the steam workshop or a dedicated mod site like nexus. If you want to add real cars you need to search around for them on all sorts of sites and clearing the cache to fix texture bugs removes them you'll always need to keep backups. In the end it's just a fairly fun way to pass some time but the mechanics and sound aren't polished enough to get immersed into it. Because there is no real objective it's hard to call it a game. It's more like software with games in it and mostly challenges you make for yourself right now. Gotta use your imagination until it gets to the point where you don't have to.Overall it's pretty good for an alpha car/physics sim but nowhere near beta or release quality. I'd wait for proper mod support unless you are a car enthusiast in which case I'd suggest buying it whenever it is on sale.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have been playing this game for quite some time, months before this early access release on steam. I have to say, as a game in and of itself, it isn't great, but the destruction is very satisfying, and it is VERY fun to play around with different things. There are also plenty of mods on the internet, so you can add content, although it is not always stable. With that being said, I think this game should be bought because of the technology, and the possible implications of these same soft body physics in future games. If they really get this right, I think we could have some really incredible racing sims among other things. Don't get me wrong, though, I really do enjoy playing the game in its current state, but I think you should buy it for the possibility of some amazing games in the future with similar soft-body collision physics.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game. This god damn game. I have had this game for around 2 years, give or take a few months, and I have got my money back 10 fold. I have downloaded more mods than you can shake a giant stick at and never found it boring. With the steam release I have been more than impressed with the content, everything seems to be completely stable and one of the most beautiful games to look at, not only graphically but also physically. I have been so impressed with this game I have even bought it twice! When I lost my account a while back, I decided that I should help the developers out a bit and just buy it again! There are games like Wreckfest, which i own, but I have never seen content being added this fast and with this quality. Just buy this game. I would of recommended it more at it's old price, £9.99, but still at £18.99 it's still worth every penny. You may not like this game, you may not like it at it's current state, but just give it a go. Steam have refunds now so you can return it if it really isn't your thing, but I would recommend keeping it for a while just to see where it is going. I would also sign up to the forums of BeamNG, they have a really great community that I am proud to call myself part of. This game is going to places you cant even imagine. Get along for the ride.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								This review is based on the alpha version of the game, up to the date August 11th, 2014.If you like realism, destruction, and cars, this is the game for you. I'd like to begin by discussing what exactly Drive is. Drive is a state-of-the-art physics simulator that runs Torque 3D as the main physics engine. In this environment, every movement and input is calculted and recalculted over and over again as the game moves. So, as you come around a corner with your tail out, the computer is taking your car's weight, road surface, throttle, brake, gas, size of the contact patch of the tires, and many more variables into account every second. This allows the game to make an accurate representation of what is going on. Continuing with my example, if you nicked a bump in the road, millions more calcultions would take place, throwing the car around and whatnot. Another important feature that is simulated is air, which, for the time being, is being experimented with."So, what do you do in this physics game?" Well, most of us from the beginning have been obsessed with cars and destroying them, so, that's what we do. We take vans and drop them onto hatchbacks; we take hatchs, and put jets on them, and then run them into the wall at 300mph. We also create the game. Due to the producing company's small size (under 15 people total at last check), the community up until now has aided in adding content to the game in the form of maps, vehicles, UI apps (compass, speedo's, tachs, etc), and more. Others constantly push the game, such as accidently making a working plane and several helicopters that are flyable (albiet with primitive controls, depending on the model). As a gamer, having all of this content available for free is awesome. And it's usually good quality stuff that the creators have put hours and weeks into. And it's free. "I'm a creator/artist/coder/computer wizz. How can I get involved?"I'm not sure how this'll work with the game porting over to Steam, but up until now, you would do whatever you'd normally create aand then put in the game. It's quite simple, and the game itself is built to be modded easily (the devs even have a wiki on how to do it). Modelors can make their models in any 3D program, export to COLLADA, create a "JBeam" file, and you're in. Obviously it takes more than just that, but it's a very straight-forward process that even a beginner could do successfully."Should I buy this?"Yes. There's more in the game that can be covered in this review without getting boring, but it is an extremely well-done game. Even though it's only in alpha, it's a pretty good game. Tech support from the community and devs is great, and gme-wide issues are quickly resolved. The physics are great and getting better, the view is spectacular, and who doesn't like smashing cars into each other? Oh, and did I mention the DLC is free? The DLC is free.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you love cars and all the physic's that go with them, then this game is for you. If' you're looking for the next racing game however, keep looking. BeamNG is the most realistic physic's simulatior I've ever played, is it perfect? Absolutly not. But it's very very good, among the best of the few games it compares to. It is so easy to turn on some music, or listen to book on tape and get lost for hours on end just driving around in your sandbox, racing, crashing, towing, testing or just exploring. Perhaps most importantly the dev's actually care about this game...One of the drawbacks to buying / playing early access game's is that it is often a gamble. A lot time's the devs become tired with their product and halt devolpment all together, leaving you with a hole in your wallet and a half finished product that'll never be more than that. That however, is not the case here. I owned this game for almost a year now, and throughout that year I have witnessed consistent improvements, patch's and added content. I cannot praise this game enough, I don't have the time to invest thousands of hours playing games like some people do. But I beleive this is my second most played game on steam...Only surpassed by Skyrim, and for the record BeamNG is closing fast on my Skyrim hours. The game has a decent arsenal of vehicles, ranging from your run of the mill work truck (which can modified to suit your taste) to Race cars, to Semi tractor trailers. And the fact, that this game is Steam Workshop compatible mean's that even more vehicle's and track's are just a click away!I'm trying to think of some potential ''con's'' to weigh in with all the ''pro's'' that go with this game. Personally I would like to see even more customization implimented into the game, such as the ability to tune gear ratio's in the transmission and fine tune things like aero dynamics. It would also be nice to be able to add specific upgrade's to your vehicle's engine. As it stand's right now, most vehicle's have Stage 1 Stage 2 and Stage 3 engine tune's and/or intake's that give you three stage's of horsepower/torque. But that's really just cherry picking on my behalf. Let's see what else, For those of you who enjoy playing with others...This is not your game. To my knowledge it currently does not have any form of multiplayer. No internet race's, I heard one time that it has split screen playability, but it's not something I've ever tried to use. I've heard some complaint's that this game only run's good on bad♥♥♥♥♥desktops, which is not completely true, however their's some truth in that statement. My current desktop was top the of line...Eight years ago, which my graphic's turned down a bit I can run most of BeamNG just fine. Howver, until I get a new computer I cannot play on certian level's...Like Moab, it's just to much for my old machine. On the side of sound, it's currently fairly weak. All vehicle's sound the same, a turbo I4 sounds excatly the same as a modified big block V8 in this game, so there isn't a huge veriety in that area, but hopefully that'll be improved upon in future patch's...Personally I just play with the sound off and listen to Reddit horror stories on Youtube while playing. With that said, It's time to tally up the Pro's and Con's.(Pros)AMAZING Physics.Reliable Devs who invest in their product to make consistent improvementsPotential to get lost for hours playing.Immense depth in level's, lot's of exploration to be done.Decent veriety of vehicle's ranging from Pickups to Race cars to Semi's.Supports Steam Workshop, meaning downloadedable vehicle's and tracks are just a click away.(Cons)Taxing to run at high resolution.Needs a little more depth in vehicle tuning.Lame sound effects.In it's current state I give this game a solid (9/10)It was worth every penny I spent on it. I hope you enjoyed this review!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've owned Beamng Drive for a few years now, and the constant updates really make it a "game" I look forward to playing each update. The physics and graphics feel very realistic, and I even used Beamng to practice driving before I got a licence (and it actually helped). The fact that you can do everything with your car in the game as you can in the real world is truly impressive. Being able to turn on the headlights, blinkers, horn, in cab lights, as well as change the configuration of the engine and body (and have those parts affect the feel and physics of the car) is my favorite thing about beamng. With enough modding you can even put wings on your car and fly which is both hillarious and impressive that the physics engine can use aerodynamics to affect the drag and lift of your vehicle at high speeds. Finally the best part of Beamng is the community, constantly pouring out new cars and objects (even buildings) that can be destroyed as well as new locations to play in with plently of fun content to choose from. Beamng is certainly a fun experience and you may find yourself playing for long periods of time without realizing it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								BeamNG Drive Early Access. I bought this game a while back and I finally got a Steam key. So here is my review. BeamNG Drive is a driving simulator but not really. I think it is more of a vehicle crash simulator. The crash physics are great and the driving physics are getting there. I really like it. The biggest thing that bugs me is the computer performance. Now, I may not have a gaming PC but I can play other games on medium-high graphics and have no trouble. But on this game, it struggles. A little problem is clipping and fall-through. Clipping is when I crash into another vehicle and the textures clip into each other. Therefore wedging the cars together. Fall-through is my term when a car falls through another car. For example, loading the hatchback into the box truck (of course I remove the doors). I drive the car in and it falls out the bottom of the truck. The bad parts are little enough where the good parts stand out. Overall, a great game. I recommend it.

content:

Early Access Review
								I love Beamng.drive. I just hooked up my Xbox One controller to it and I've been having a blast. There are so many community created maps and vehicles and such. Physics are amazing.Well, I was having a blast.Now, as of around the 23rd, whenever I am on the start screen, I move my mouse the slightest inch and my frames drop to 0. And then I wait. And then they go back up to 60 ish, way less than what I was getting before this issue happened, when I was getting around 300-500 fps. This only affects the menu screen, but then when I finally load into the map, it brings me to my second issue, below.I have since lost all my vehicles and maps, and whenever I go into the files to make sure they weren't deleted, they are there. But in-game, they are simply not there. Gone like they were never there in the first place. Again, it's a beautiful game, with plenty of things to mess around with, and create some painstakingly accurate car crashes, if that's what you want. The physics are accurate down to the smallest dent, and I'm waiting for the multiplayer so that we can all turn our cars and trucks into flattened pancakes of metal.I'm checking the recommended box, just because I know that the developers can easily get over this simple, but very irritating issue.Fix your♥♥♥♥♥♥ Beamng, and I will play again.
